claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so dollars must be exchanged for euros when traveling there.

attacks.text: France uses the euro as its official currency, so dollars must be exchanged for euros when traveling there.
Many travelers use credit cards that automatically convert currencies, eliminating the need to physically exchange dollars for euros.
Credit card transactions may incur foreign exchange fees, making physical currency exchange more economical in some cases.
Some businesses in France accept dollars directly, though at unfavorable exchange rates.
Accepting dollars is rare and typically limited to tourist-heavy areas, making it unreliable for most travelers.

supporting.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, so dollars must be exchanged for krone when traveling there.

attacks.text: Denmark uses the Danish krone as its official currency, so dollars must be exchanged for krone when traveling there.
Some businesses in Denmark accept euros or credit cards, reducing the need to exchange dollars for krone.
Even if some businesses accept euros or credit cards, many local services and smaller vendors still require krone, making currency exchange necessary.
Travelers can use multi-currency debit cards to withdraw krone directly from ATMs, bypassing traditional currency exchange.
ATM withdrawals often incur foreign transaction fees and poor exchange rates, making direct currency exchange more cost-effective.

supporting.text: The euro is the legal tender in France, requiring currency exchange from dollars for transactions.

attacks.text: The euro is the legal tender in France, requiring currency exchange from dollars for transactions.
Some businesses in France accept dollars, especially in tourist-heavy areas, reducing the need for currency exchange.
Even if some businesses accept dollars, the exchange rate offered is typically unfavorable compared to official currency exchange services.
Travelers can use credit or debit cards that automatically handle currency conversion, avoiding the need to physically exchange dollars for euros.
Foreign transaction fees and dynamic currency conversion charges on cards can make this method more expensive than exchanging currency in advance.

supporting.text: The Danish krone is the legal tender in Denmark, requiring currency exchange from dollars for transactions.

attacks.text: The Danish krone is the legal tender in Denmark, requiring currency exchange from dollars for transactions.
Many businesses in Denmark accept euros or credit cards, reducing the need for currency exchange.
Acceptance of euros in Denmark is limited to tourist areas, and credit cards may incur foreign transaction fees.
Some travelers use multi-currency accounts or digital wallets to avoid physical currency exchange.
Multi-currency accounts and digital wallets are not universally accessible and may have usage restrictions.

supporting.text: Currency exchange is necessary in France because businesses and services operate exclusively in euros.

attacks.text: Currency exchange is necessary in France because businesses and services operate exclusively in euros.
Some businesses in France, especially in tourist-heavy areas, accept major foreign currencies like USD.
Even if some businesses accept USD, exchange rates offered by them are often unfavorable compared to official exchange services.
Digital payment methods like credit cards automatically handle currency conversion, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Credit card transactions may incur foreign exchange fees, making direct currency exchange a more cost-effective option for large purchases.

supporting.text: Currency exchange is necessary in Denmark because businesses and services operate exclusively in Danish krone.

attacks.text: Currency exchange is necessary in Denmark because businesses and services operate exclusively in Danish krone.
Many businesses in Denmark, especially in tourist areas, accept euros or credit cards, reducing the need for krone exchange.
Even if some businesses accept euros or cards, local services like public transport or small shops often require krone, making exchange necessary.
Denmark is part of the EU's single market, and some places may unofficially accept euros despite the official currency being krone.
Unofficial euro acceptance is unreliable and not legally enforceable, so travelers should still exchange currency to avoid issues.
